Years in Review

Those who fail to refuse to learn from history are condemned to repeat it.

This page chronicles the major events that have affected the Bahamas starting from the year 2000.

Table of Contents

  • 2016
  • 2015
  • 2014
  • 2013
  • 2012
  • 2011
  • 2010
  • 2009
  • 2008
  • 2007
  • 2006
  • 2005
  • 2004
  • 2003
  • 2002
  • 2001
  • 2000

2016

  1. March - Potential Ebola case in the Bahamas [Ref]
  2. August - Zika cases confirmed in the Bahamas. CDC adds country to interim alert list [Ref]
  3. FNM Chairman Michael Pintard resigns as chairman and senator amid ongoing Peter Nygard &/Louis Bacon scandal [Ref]
  4. Second Bahamian Carnival held [Ref]
  5. Bahamians vote to deny women equal rights - again [Ref]
  6. Moody’s downgrades Bahamas’ credit rating to baa3, two ranks away from junk status, with stable outlook [Ref]
  7. Hurricane Matthew devastates Bahamas [Ref]
  8. *BPL takes over BEC [Ref]
  9. PLP Bamboo Town MP Renward Wells and PLP Fort Charlotte MP Dr. Andre Rollins join the FNM [Ref]
  10. *FNM Minister of State joins the PLP [Ref]
  11. Simone Cambridge of Queen’s College named ABMS to attend McGill University to study Art History & Urban Studies [Ref]
  12. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2015 [Ref]
  13. Murder count: ??? [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2015

  1. Perry Christie says Baha Mar is not running out of cash (May 2015) [Ref]
  2. Baha Mar files for bankruptcy (July 2015) [Ref]
  3. Government budgets $9 million, spends $12.9 million on carnival [Ref]
  4. Fred Smith demands the immediate passage of a Freedom of Information Act [Ref]
  5. Rubis fuel spill in Marathon potentially exposes residents to cancer-causing agents [Ref]
  6. MPs vote overwhelmingly against appointing a committee to investigate the Rubis gasoline spill of 2012 (*info on this spill) [Ref]
  7. Minimum wage increase from $150 to $210 per week planned to go into effect on August 15th [Ref]
  8. Hurricane Joaquin devastates the Bahamas [Ref]
  9. Marco City MP Gregory Moss resigns from the PLP to form the United Democratic Party [Ref]
  10. Damian Gomez, Minister of State for Legal Affairs and MP for Central and South Eleuthera, resigned from Perry Christie’s cabinet [Ref]
  11. Sea Wall constructed in response to expectation that Bahamas will lose 80% of land by the end of the century 149 murders, high levels of violent armed crimes, highest recorded to date [Ref]
  12. Value added tax (VAT) goes into effect [Ref]
  13. Domonic McDonald named ABMS to attend the University of Western Ontario and study Political Science and International Relations [Ref]
  14. The Royal Bahamas Police Force reports an 18 percent decrease in crime overall for 2014 [Ref]
  15. Highest recorded crime rate ever? - last was 2014 [Ref]
  16. Murder count: 149 - Highest recorded ever [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2014

  1. Baha Mar announces it will not be ready to open in time [Ref]
  2. Moody’s downgrades Bahamas’ credit rating to baa2 and changes outlook to stable [Ref]
  3. Groups unite for freedom of information rally [Ref]
  4. Audit reveals $10 million deficit in pharmacy inventory between the physical count and what was reflected on the Princess Margaret Hospital information systems [Ref]
  5. Resolution passes in House to borrow $16.1 million to transition COB to university status (same reference as PMH 10 million deficit) [Ref]
  6. Dr. Hubert Minnis defeats Loretta Butler-Turner to retain leadership of the FNM [Ref]
  7. Gabrielle Moss from XYZ named ABMS to attend Johns Hopkins University and study Applied Mathematics [Ref]
  8. Princess Margaret Hospital reports 40 more rape cases in 2013 than Royal Bahamas Police Force reports. [Ref]
  9. Princess Margaret Hospital reports 519 shot or stabbed in 2013 while Royal Bahamas Police Force reports 10 attempted murders. Accuracy of RBPF statistics questioned. [Ref]
  10. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2013 [Ref]
  11. Murder count: 122 - Third highest murder rate among 13 Caribbean countries again [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2013

  1. Referendum to legalize gambling and establish national lottery defeated after at least $1.5 million spent on advertising for a yes vote [Ref]
    • Why referendums are a terrible way to do anything* [Ref]
  2. Final stage of airport reconstruction completed [Ref]
  3. Perry Christie refuses to answer whether Lyford Cay billionaire Peter Nygard donated money to the PLP, Peter states he has [Ref]
  4. Several PLP MPs filmed at private meeting with Peter Nygard [Ref]
    • For more on Peter Nygard and his stem cell research center, click [here]
  5. The Royal Bahamas Defense Force refuses to investigate claims that one of its officers raped and impregnated a 24 year old Cuban woman while at the Carmichael Road Detention Center. They had just completed an investigation into claims its officers beat male Cuban detainees. [Ref]
  6. Value Added Tax discussed for implementation in 2014.[Ref]
  7. Shannon Butler from Queen’s College named ABMS to attend St. Andrew’s University and study Medicine [Ref]
  8. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2012 [Ref]
  9. Murder count: 119 - Third highest murder rate among 13 Caribbean countries[Ref]

Up to table of contents

2012

  1. PLP wins election in landslide [Ref]
  2. Hubert Ingraham resigns as FNM party leader and as MP [Ref]
  3. Dr. Hubert Minnis wins unopposed to be new FNM party leader [Ref]
  4. Limited overseas voting becomes available [Ref]
  5. National debt stands at $5 billion - 50% of GDP. [Ref]
  6. Unemployment nationwide is 15.9% [Ref]
  7. Moody’s downgrades Bahamas’ credit rating to baa1 with negative outlook [Ref]
  8. Hurricane Sandy devastates the Bahamas. [Ref]
  9. Rubis gasoline spill of 2012 (*info on this spill) [Ref]
  10. Theophilus Moss from St. Augustine’s College named ABMS to attend Johns Hopkins University and study Mechanical Engineering [Ref]
  11. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2011 [Ref]
  12. Murder count: 111 - First decrease since 2008, second consecutive year over 100, 26% unsolved by the end of the year [Ref]
  13. 97 rapes recorded across the Bahamas - 12 (additional) attempted, and 167 (additional) statutory [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2011

  1. Government finalizes BTC privatization deal [Ref]
  2. Branville McCartney resigns from the FNM and forms the DNA [Ref]
  3. New sport stadium to be constructed via financial assistance from the Chinese government will be top-knotch sporting facility [Ref]
  4. Moody’s revises Bahamas outlook from stable to negative [Ref]
  5. First stage of airport reconstruction completed [Ref]
  6. Hurricane Irene devastates Bahamas [Ref]
  7. Jamia Moss from St. Augustine’s College named ABMS to attend the College of St. Benedict and study Biochemistry and Spanish [Ref]
  8. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2010 [Ref]
  9. Murder count: 127 - Highest recorded to date and ~50% were unsolved by the end of the year [Ref]
  10. 107 rapes recorded across the Bahamas - 84 on New Providence, 28 (additional) attempted, and 179 (additional) statutory rapes [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2010

  1. Tropical storm Nicole hits the Bahamas [Ref]
  2. Clifford Bowe named ABMS to attend Georgia Institute of Technology [Ref]
  3. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2009 [Ref]
  4. Murder count: 94 - Highest recorded to date and 5th highest among 15 caribbean countries at that time [Ref]
  5. 54 rapes recorded on New Providence [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2009

  1. Marital rape bill put forward by FNM but withdrawn due to public criticism [Ref]
  2. New Providence Road Improvement Project begins with a budget of $60 million and a timeline of 33.5 months.
    • It would be completed after 48 months at over $240 million, four times the original amount [Ref]
  3. Jenna Chaplin named ABMS to attend University of The Pacific and study Fine Arts and Psychology [Ref]
  4. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2008 [Ref]
  5. Murder count: 87 - Highest recorded to date [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2008

  1. A global financial crisis begins which will drastically affect nearly every country on Earth [Ref]
  2. Hurricane Hanna devastates the Bahamas. [Ref]
  3. Genymphas Higgs named ABMS to attend Drexel University and study Biomedical Engineering [Ref]
  4. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2007 [Ref]
  5. Murder count: 72 [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2007

  1. Plans for Baha Mar announced [Ref]
  2. FNM wins election and inherits $8 million in budget surplus - which will turn into a $600 million deficit by 2012 [Ref]
  3. Lisa Rodgers from St. Andrews named ABMS to attend Brown University and study Education [Ref]
  4. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2006 [Ref]
  5. Murder count: 78 - Highest recorded to date [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2006

  1. Highest crime rate ever! [Ref]
  2. Kyle Chea named ABMS to attend Vassar College to study Medicine and Foreign Languages [Ref]
  3. Murder count: 60 [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2005

  1. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2004 [Ref]
  2. Hurricane Katrina and Wilma devastates the Bahamas. [Ref]
  3. Andrea Culmer named ABMS to attend McGill University to study Chemistry / Medicine [Ref]
  4. Murder count: 50 [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2004

  1. Highest recorded crime rate ever - last was 2002 [Ref]
  2. Bahamians protest the arrival of thousands of gay cruise ship passengers and their families in Nassau on July 16, 2004 [Ref]
  3. Hurricane Frances and Hurricane Jeanne [Ref]
  4. Sharelle Ferguson named ABMS to attend Harvard University and study Social Studies [Ref]
  5. Murder count: 44 [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2003

  1. Moody’s changes Bahamas’ A3 rating outlook from positive to stable [Ref]
  2. Sebastian Hutchinson named ABMS to attend the University of Pennsylvania and study Finance and Accounting [Ref]
  3. Murder count: 50 [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2002

  1. Bahamians vote to deny women equal rights [Ref]
  2. The PLP defeat the governing FNM in the election [Ref]
  3. Moody’s changes Bahamas’ A3 rating outlook from stable to positive [Ref]
  4. Dr. Peter Blair from St. Andrew’s named ABMS to attend Duke University and study Physics and Mathematics [Ref]
  5. Highest recorded crime rate ever! [Ref]
  6. Murder count: 52 [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2001

  1. 9/11 occurs and consequent measures lengthen the check-in process for Bahamians traveling to the US for vacation [Ref]
  2. Moody’s changes Bahamas’ A3 rating outlook from positive to stable [Ref]
  3. Hurricane Michelle hits the Bahamas [Ref]
  4. Murder count: 43 [Ref]

Up to table of contents

2000

  1. Ricardo Davis named All Bahamas Merit Scholar (ABMS) to attend Queen’s University and study Biochemistry [Ref]
  2. Murder count: 73 [Ref]
